Award.AwardTitle: Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion in Herpetology and Ichthyology
Award.AbstractNarration: Research and experience support the assertion that having a more diverse and inclusive team of individuals improves outcomes in research and training. By broadening participation for underrepresented groups, we open doors to new ideas and new breakthroughs. This symposium and related workshop for students in the biology of fishes, amphibians, and reptiles, will showcase data- and experience-driven presentations by speakers who will not only discuss the merits of diversity, equity, and inclusion in science, but will provide training on how to implement workable strategies for these initiatives. A strong mentoring program will actively bring and support undergraduate students into the field, which will have long-term benefits for the scientific community at large.<br/><br/>This symposium and workshop, to be held in conjunction with the annual Joint Meeting of Ichthyologists and Herpetologists (JMIH) in July 2021, will promote a more inclusive environment for underrepresented groups in the fields of herpetology and ichthyology. Increasing participation in these fields will have dramatic effects across biology. The goal is to increase diversity and equity through three activities: 1) increase the dialog among professional societies regarding the importance of diversity, equity, and inclusion in science; 2) provide support for undergraduate and graduate students, especially those from URGs, through a network of mentors; and 3) provide an interactive workshop that will enable participants to recognize the role of social identity in the scientific enterprise equip them to better serve mentees from diverse backgrounds.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this symposium and activities was to improve diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) in the field of herpetology and ichthyology, specifically centered around the annual Joint Meeting of Ichthyology and Herpetology (JMIH). Our mentoring program specifically targeted students from underrepresented groups (URG)s to provide them with financial and experiential support. The workshop gave tools to participants to improve their own understanding of DEI issues, which should have long-term benefits for URGs in science.

This award helped to bring 13 speakers to represent many different issues and demographics. The talks were well-attended during this full day symposium. Informal responses indicated that the existence of the symposium and the subjects that were discussed helped many individuals feel as though they were, for the first time, being represented at JMIH. The speakers represented early career individuals, individuals traditionally underrepresented in science, and focused on enhancing the experience of those traditionally underrepresented in science.

The mentorship program helped to directly fund nine undergraduate students to attend the JMIH meeting. Two students (asterisk) attended the meeting remotely due to personal and health issues. Students were selected randomly after filling out an online interest form that was circulated on social media and through the three participating JMIH societies.

There were approximately 50 people who were able to benefit from the Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion workshop that was implemented on the day of the symposium. This was the first workshop available to the general membership at a JMIH meeting.

There is a broad understanding that increasing participation from underrepresented groups helps to address complex questions that face society today. Societal problems such as global climate change, invasive species, and the spread of novel diseases require a diverse team of individuals working together to solve. This project enhances the scientific environment for underrepresented groups, which will enable more diverse, equitable, and inclusive teams to address these significant challenges.
